input:
######################## number of models # Number of models for which details are described in this input file 4 ######################## restart # Restart from previous (pickled) population? False
######################## epsilon schedule # Automatic epsilon schedule. Provide a vector of final epsilons and the alpha (defaults to 0.9) # OR # Series of epsilons. (Whitespace delimited list) # Multiple epsilon schedules can be specified by giving additional vectors enclosed in , etc # NOTE: the parser always reads them in order and ignores the tag value
1.0 0.9
######################## particles 100
######################## beta # Beta is the number of times to simulate each sampled parameter set. # This is only applicable for models simulated using Gillespie and SDE 1
######################## dt # Internal timestep for solver. # Make this small for a stiff model. 0.01
######################## perturbation kernels : OPTIONAL (default uniform) # The pertubation kernels are computed with respect to the previous parameter distribution # Currently uniform and normal are implemented uniform
######################## model kernel : OPTIONAL (default 0.7) # Probability of perturbing the sampled model (ignored when modelnumber = 1) 0.7
######################## ODE solver control : OPTIONAL # rtol and atol can be specified here. If the model is stiff then making these small might help the simulation to run 1e-2 1e-4
######################## User-supplied data
# times: For ABC SMC, times must be a whitespace delimited list # In simulation mode these are the timepoints for which the simulations will be output 0 142.8 285.7 428.5 571.4 714.2 857.1 1000
# variables: For ABC SMC, whitespace delimited lists of concentrations (ODE or SDE) or molecule numbers (Gillespie) # Denote your data via tags or or etc. # The tags are ignored and the data read in order # For simulation these data are ignored # See fitting instruction below if the dimensionality of your data sets differ from the dimensionality of your model
20.00667852389437 60.61216368988336 129.15382976361977 160.94770380950294 167.13973577865534 168.0444204765364 168.20277670996927 168.22288662735917 19.991732700731877 60.58317273344466 129.1408440571498 160.93778130566355 167.1299925347945 168.0676080758877 168.18978134982405 168.19844761482938 19.98466829242517 60.60898763705779 129.15445130775765 160.9470905892251 167.1345840698311 168.0706483616953 168.20459315989754 168.22521227376407
######################## Models
model1 model1.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. ODE
# Fitting information. # If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmetic operations can be performed on these. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in the model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 species2 species2 species2
# Priors on initial conditions and parameters: # one of # constant, value # normal, mean, variance # uniform, lower, upper # lognormal, mean, variance
constant 200.0 constant 20.0 constant 0.0 constant 200.0
constant 1.0 lognormal 1 3 lognormal 0 1 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 9 2 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 6 1
model2 model2.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. ODE
# Fitting information. # If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmetic operations can be performed on these. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in the model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 species2 species2 species2
# Priors on initial conditions and parameters: # one of # constant, value # normal, mean, variance # uniform, lower, upper # lognormal, mean, variance
constant 200.0 constant 20.0 constant 0.0 constant 200.0
constant 1.0 lognormal 1 3 lognormal 0 1 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 9 2
model3 model3.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. ODE
# Fitting information. # If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmetic operations can be performed on these. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in the model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 species2 species2 species2
# Priors on initial conditions and parameters: # one of # constant, value # normal, mean, variance # uniform, lower, upper # lognormal, mean, variance
constant 200.0 constant 20.0 constant 0.0 constant 200.0
constant 1.0 lognormal 1 3 lognormal 0 1 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 9 2 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 6 1 constant 0 1 constant 6 1
model4 model4.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. ODE
# Fitting information. # If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmetic operations can be performed on these. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in the model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 species2 species2 species2
# Priors on initial conditions and parameters: # one of # constant, value # normal, mean, variance # uniform, lower, upper # lognormal, mean, variance
constant 200.0 constant 20.0 constant 0.0 constant 200.0
constant 1.0 lognormal 1 3 lognormal 0 1 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 9 2 lognormal 1 1 lognormal 6 1
